pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.4: Sp.1.505: Tattha yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṃ pitāmahayugaṃ, “In this yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means: the father of a father is a grandfather. The generation of a grandfather is called a pitāmahayuga.” So the PaIi phrase yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means “as far as the seventh generation of grandfathers”, that is, eight generations back. This can be counted as follows: (1) one’s grandfather; (2) his father; (3) 2’s father; (4) 3’s father; (5) 4’s father; (6) 5’s father; and (7) 6’s father. This applies to both one’s paternal and maternal grandfathers. This gives a total of 14 ancestors. Anyone who is a descendent of these fourteen is considered a relative. Anyone who is not such a descendent is not regarded as a relative.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.6: Agāraṁ is typically rendered as "in a house". The problem with this is that it is not unallowable for a monastic to live in a building that is the equivalent of a house. What a monastic should not do is own a home and then live there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.12: The six are linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp; see Kd 8:3.1.6. | According to Kd 8:21.1.4 this is no smaller than 8 by 4 sugataṅgula, “standard fingerbreadths”.
